description:
Managing Emotions

“I don't want to be at the mercy of my emotions. I want to use them, to enjoy them, and to dominate them.”
- Oscar Wilde

 

What is your relationship to your emotions? Are you a slave or a master when it comes to managing your emotions? What are the connections between emotional mastery, freedom, wisdom and happiness?
There has been so much great work done on empowering oneself through the mastery of emotions that I thought this would be an ideal topic for our group. This event will be an opportunity for us to explore wisdom and insights from some of the great philosophers of the past and present, as well as a forum for us to share our insights, theories, thoughts, and experiences.

 

No formal philosophy experience or specialized knowledge is required to participate in any of our events (either as a facilitator or as a regular guest). All that is required is that you are open-minded and respectful of your fellow guests. :)


 

Venue Selection

Thanks to Cristina for suggesting Le Wine Bar du Sablon for this event.

Click here for venue details</a>


 

 

Food for Thought

Facilitator Information

As previously mentioned, our members take turns helping to facilitate our discussions. We require one discussion facilitator for each table of 6 people but I doubt that we`ll have a problem finding volunteers. I`ve created a special video just to explain what is involved with facilitating our discussions.

<a href="http://www.philosophydinners.org/events/Notes-Managing-Emotions.html">Click here for the facilitator notes for this event

 

Please Note:

If you would like to attend this event then you need to sign up as a member and RSVP for this event on-line through this website only. Please do not show up in person if you haven't signed up since there are limited seats available and this will cause confusion.
Please try to arrive on time (in consideration of your fellow attendees). Don't be shy to sign up to this event since I'll cancel if less than 6 people sign up.  

Arrival time is 7:00pm at which time everyone will be provided a seat at one of our reserved tables (6 people max at each table). We will start our discussions at 7:15 once people have settled and have ordered their drinks/food. As a courtesy to your fellow attendees and to the facilitators, please arrive on time.

 

Looking for some more motivation to sign up?

Click here to view some feedback from our members

 

Thanks for being part of this ongoing experiment!

Glen

P.S.

Click here to take a sneak peak at our upcoming topics

 

Glen Brauer
Founder, Facilitator, and Event Coordinator
PhilosophyConnections
PhilosophyConnections.org
name: Managing Emotions (dinner and discussion)

description:
"My philosophy, in essence, is the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute." - Ayn Rand

Can Objectivism help give us a clearer view of the world?

Can Objectivism help us to live happier lives?

Can Objectivism give us a different perspective on the nature of self-interest?


Objectivism remains to be a popular movement to this day around the world. So what is all the controversy about? As with all of our events we will be taking a practical look at Objectivism and how it can be applied to our lives with respect to happiness and wisdom.

Please note that the decision to select Objectivism for this event is neither to promote nor to condemn this philosophy; as that's up for you to decide for yourself.

No formal philosophy experience or specialized knowledge is required to participate in any of our events (either as a facilitator or as a regular guest). All that is required is that you are open-minded and respectful of your fellow guests. :)

description:

One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to compel us to seek out ways to deal with the conundrum of managing truth and honesty in our modern world; both with those around us, and within ourselves. This event will allow us to sink our teeth into some interesting areas within this subject. As usual, our facilitators will be provided with though-provoking questions to fuel the discussions.

One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us tools to better manage ethical and moral challenges in daily life. This event will provide the opportunity to delve into some interesting sub-topics within this theme from a practical perspective.


PLEASE REMEMBER to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to attending this event:

Click here to view the Food for Thought page for this event



FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS

- Can I just show up in person and pay at the door? No, all members much pay on-line via this Meetup page since there are a limited number of physical seats at our events and it has been proven that people who pay online for Meetup events are much more likely to actually show up. You don't need a PayPal account - just follow the RSVP steps and look for the link to pay with your credit card. Click here for more payment FAQs

- Why is there a small fee for these events? Click here to view the 7 reasons why there is a small fee for attending our events

- Do I need to have any formal philosophy experience to be part of these events? No, this is not required. Click here to find out more about the nature of our events

- How can I find out more about Philosophy Dinners? Click here to visit PhilosophyDinners.org

name: Ethics and Morals (dinner and discussion)

description:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M9WtX-A0r1A

One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us a deeper understanding of our limitations and opportunities in the realm of freedom. This discussion will include the following four subtopics: personal responsibility, free will (the main portion), freedom from fear, and freedom from the self. As usual, our facilitators will be provided with discussion notes to keep the conversations on topic (at least for the first 90 minutes).


PLEASE REMEMBER to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to attending this event:

You don't need a PayPal account - just follow the RSVP steps and look for the link to pay with your credit card. Click here for more payment FAQs

- Why is there a small fee for these events? Click here to view the 7 reasons why there is a small fee for attending our events

- Do I need to have any formal philosophy experience to be part of these events? No, this is not required. Click here to find out more about the nature of our events

- More questions? Click here to visit our main FAQ page


Facilitator Information

As previously mentioned, our members take turns helping to facilitate our discussions. We require one discussion facilitator for each table of 6 people so please leave a comment below (i.e. "I'll help facilitate") if you're able to help out at this event. No facilitation experience is required.

Click here to view the facilitator notes for this event



Please see our home page for more information:

name: Freedom (dinner and discussion)

description:
One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us a deeper understanding of the delicate balance between rights and freedoms as well as our duties as citizens in matters of church and state.

PLEASE REMEMBER to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to attending this event:

Click here to view the Food for Thought page for this event


Please don't be afraid to sign up for this event since I will cancel it and provide refunds if less than 5 people sign up. If the event is full then please remember to add yourself to the waiting list since I will open up the event to additional tables if I can see that there is enough demand to do so.


What makes this topic so important?

The scope of religious influence on rights and freedoms covers the spectrum from matters of birth (i.e. abortion) to death (i.e. euthanasia), marriage (i.e. same-sex marriage), medical research (i.e. stem cell controversy) and many other issues which affect us all. Even if you believe that your country has a firm separation of church and state we are no longer living in an age where one government's actions have no consequences for other countries. Please note, if your only interest in this topic is to rant about religion (or rant about anything else for that matter) then please do not sign up for this event. This purpose of this event is to have a respectful and engaging discussion focusing on insights and ideas regarding the separation of church and state with respect to both religious and non-religious fellow human beings. Click here to view the format for our events.

The sub-topics in this discussion will include:

National Identity (i.e. the use of religious words and phrases in currency, national anthems, and in public spaces)

Rights and Freedoms (i.e. religion in public schools, oaths involved with swearing in new citizens, religious references in political speeches, etc)

Opportunities for Change (sharing ideas and actions we can take to produce change) for the sake of creating more aware and engaged global citizens and to reaffirm the importance of how one person can make a difference.

As usual, our facilitators will be provided with discussion questions to keep the conversations on topic (at least for the first 90 minutes).

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS

- Can I just show up in person and pay at the door? No, all members must pay on-line via this Meetup page since there are a limited number of physical seats at our events and it has been proven that people who pay online for Meetup events are much more likely to actually show up. You don't need a PayPal account - just follow the RSVP steps and look for the link to pay with your credit card. Click here for more payment FAQs

- Why is there a small fee for these events? Click here to view the 7 reasons why there is a small fee for attending our events

- Do I need to have any formal philosophy experience to be part of these events? No, this is not required. Click here to find out more about the nature of our events

- More questions? Click here to visit our main FAQ page


Facilitator Information

As previously mentioned, our members take turns helping to facilitate our discussions. We require one discussion facilitator for each table of 6 people so please leave a comment below (i.e. "I'll help facilitate") if you're able to help out at this event. No facilitation experience is required.

Click here to view the facilitator notes for this event



Please see our home page for more information:

name: Church and State (dinner and discussion)

description:
One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us a deeper understanding of our relationship with death.

This event will provide a proactive, respectful and engaging forum for us to discuss this delicate topic which touches us all. We will also be discussing ideas and implications around what it means to be human with regards to radical life extension and immortality (transcendence).

Please remember to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to the event:

Click here to view the Food for Thought page for this event


As per usual, our discussion facilitators will be provided with thought-provoking questions to fuel the discussions. Our members take turns facilitating these discussions. As the coordinator for all of our groups around the world, I'm the one who coordinates the facilitators for events prior to the event taking place (with one facilitator for every table of 6 people). I also facilitate events which take place in Vancouver.


Why is there a small fee? Click here to read the reasons why there is a small fee to attend our events.


Don't be afraid to sign up for this event since I'll cancel it and provide refunds if less than 5 people sign up. Also, I'll add an additional table of 6 people if there is enough people on the waiting list.


For more information on Philosophy Dinners please visit our home page:

philosophydinners.org


Sincerely,
Glen Brauer
Founder, Facilitator and Event Coordinator
